item.title: Meta’s new move: What are Community Notes and can they really replace fact-checkers? - The Indian Express
item.description:
Meta’s new move: What are Community Notes and can they really replace fact-checkers?

Date: January 7, 2023 | Source: Indian Express

Meta's recent decision to discontinue its independent fact-checking program in the US has caused significant backlash and raised discussions about the company's strategy against misinformation.

  • The 'Community Notes' system will replace traditional fact-checking, similar to Twitter's model.
  • This shift follows criticisms of bias in expert fact-checking from Meta.
  • Officials from the International Fact-Checking Network contend that Meta's decision undermines unbiased reporting.
  • Community Notes will allow users to contribute helpful context to posts, improving with public engagement.
  • The approach aims to prevent bias by requiring diverse participation in ratings.
  • Challenges remain, including the potential for manipulation and capturing nuanced misinformation.
“Experts, like everyone else, have their own biases and perspectives.” – Meta's Blog Post

Meta's move to Community Notes could signify a broader shift in content moderation, but the effectiveness in combating misinformation remains uncertain.

Date: January 09, 2025

item.title: TCS Q3 net profit rises 11.95% to ₹12,380 crore - The Hindu
item.description:
TCS Reports 11.95% Increase in Q3 Net Profit to ₹12,380 Crore

Date: January 09, 2025 Source: The Hindu

The country's largest IT services exporter TCS reported an 11.95% jump in net profit for the December quarter, totaling ₹12,380 crore, showing growth from the previous year.

item.description:
Tata Elxsi reports 3.6% decline in net profit on-year to Rs 199 crore, revenue rises 2.7%

Date: January 09, 2025 / Source: Moneycontrol

Tata Elxsi reported a 3.6% decline in net profit for the December 2024 quarter, despite a rise in revenue. The company attributed the profit decline to geopolitical uncertainty and industry-specific challenges.

  • Net profit declined to Rs 199 crore from Rs 206.43 crore a year ago.
  • Revenue from operations increased to Rs 939.17 crore, a slight decrease from Rs 955.1 crore in the previous quarter.
  • EBITDA fell by 7.7% to Rs 220.07 crore, with a margin decrease from 25.7% to 24.2%.
  • The decline is attributed to geopolitical uncertainty, currency volatility, and challenges in Europe and the US.
“The company attributed decline to geopolitical uncertainty, currency volatility and industry specific challenges in Europe and US.”

This report highlights Tata Elxsi's challenging quarter despite a slight growth in revenue, reflecting broader market uncertainties.

item.title: Sensex, Nifty 50 fall for second consecutive session. What is driving Indian stock market down? Explained with 5 factors | Stock Market News - Mint
item.description:
Sensex, Nifty 50 fall for second consecutive session. What is driving Indian stock market down? Explained with 5 factors

Date: January 9
Source: Live Mint

In a continuation of a downward trend, the Indian stock market's benchmarks, Sensex and Nifty 50, have declined in response to a combination of weak global cues and internal economic challenges.

The recent decline can be attributed to five key factors impacting investor sentiment:

  • Q3 earnings in focus: Investors await upcoming earnings reports, creating caution in the markets.
  • Rising US bond yields and dollar: Increased bond yields are steering foreign capital away from emerging markets.
  • Heavy selling by FPIs: Foreign portfolio investors are retreating amid concerns over trade policies and interest rates.
  • Macro jitters: Economic growth concerns are significantly affecting investor risk appetite.
  • Uncertainty over US Federal Reserve policies: Speculations about inflation and policy adjustments are causing apprehension.
"The recent fall in the Indian stock market can be attributed to several interconnected factors..." - Atul Parakh, CEO of Bigul

As the situation unfolds, investors are advised to be cautious due to the prevailing market uncertainties.

item.title: Govt plans to give LPG subsidy worth Rs 35,000 cr to IOC, BPCL, and HPCL - Business Standard
item.description:
Government Plans Rs 35,000 Crore LPG Subsidy for IOC, BPCL, HPCL

Publication Date: October 2023

Source: Industry Reports

The Indian government is set to provide a Rs 35,000 crore subsidy to state-owned oil companies to compensate for their losses on the sale of domestic LPG, as they have maintained prices amidst rising raw material costs.

  • The companies affected include Indian Oil Corporation Ltd (IOC), Bharat Petroleum Corporation Ltd (BPCL), and Hindustan Petroleum Corporation Ltd (HPCL).
  • Domestic LPG prices have been held at Rs 803 per 14.2-kg cylinder since March 2024 despite higher costs, resulting in significant under-recoveries.
  • The total estimated under-recovery for the LPG sector in the current fiscal year is about Rs 40,500 crore.
  • A government provision for this subsidy is expected to be included in the Union Budget for the 2025-26 fiscal year.
  • Previous compensations of Rs 22,000 crore were also provided to these companies for the fiscal years 2021-22 and 2022-23.
“There is an under-recovery of about Rs 240 per 14.2-kg cylinder that the state-owned fuel retailers sell to domestic households.”

This subsidy aims to alleviate the financial strain on these companies and ensure the sustainability of LPG supplies to households.

item.title: Fed minutes point to slower pace of rate cuts ahead - Goldman Sachs - Investing.com
item.description:
Fed Minutes Indicate Slower Pace of Rate Cuts Ahead, Goldman Sachs Reports

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Investing.com

Minutes from the Federal Reserve's latest meeting suggest a cautious approach to interest rate cuts due to uncertainties surrounding economic policies under President-elect Donald Trump, according to analysts at Goldman Sachs.

  • The Fed's officials are concerned about the potential effects of Trump's policies on inflation.
  • Current inflation easing to the target of 2% may take longer than anticipated.
  • Recent indicators of economic activity, including private payroll data, show mixed signals.
  • The Fed has already reduced interest rates by a full percentage point in 2024.
  • Analysts predict the next rate cut may not occur until May at the earliest.
"Given the lack of concrete discussion by Fed officials, the continued assessment that reserves remain abundant... we are shifting the timing of the second QT taper that we expect back a meeting," Goldman Sachs analysts stated.

The uncertainty surrounding the economic outlook emphasizes the importance of upcoming economic indicators, particularly the US employment report.

“Despite volatile market conditions, equity-oriented schemes continued to see strong inflows, reflecting investors’ confidence and commitment to stay invested for the long term.” - Venkat Chalasani

This significant rise in inflows suggests a robust investor confidence in equity markets, despite external volatility.

item.title: Meta’s fact-checking snub in US sets off alarm bells for fact-checkers in India - The Indian Express
item.description:
Meta’s fact-checking snub in US sets off alarm bells for fact-checkers in India

Publication Date: January 9, 2025

Source: The Indian Express

Meta's recent decision to end its third-party fact-checking programme in the US has raised alarm bells for fact-checkers in India, as many rely on funding from Meta, fearing they could face significant operational challenges.

  • Meta announced the cessation of its third-party fact-checking programme in the U.S., pivoting to a community-driven model.
  • Fact-checkers in India fear potential funding cuts, as many rely on Meta for financial support.
  • The survival of these fact-checking entities is threatened if they cannot access Meta's platforms for visibility.
  • Meta works with 12 fact-checking partners in India, including notable organizations and smaller firms.
  • Uncertainty looms over whether Meta will implement similar changes in India.
“This is possibly the biggest existential threat many fact checkers will have to contend with,” a senior executive from a fact-checking organisation stated anonymously.

The shift in Meta's strategy underscores the growing concerns about the future of independent fact-checking, especially in developing contexts like India.

item.title: AMFI data: Inflow into equity mutual funds rose 14% in December 2024 vs. November | Mint - Mint
item.description:
Inflow into Equity Mutual Funds Increased by 14% in December 2024

Publication Date: January 2025
Source: Live Mint

The Association of Mutual Funds in India (AMFI) reported a significant rise in equity mutual fund inflows for December 2024, marking a 14.5% increase from the previous month.

  • Equity mutual funds recorded an inflow of ₹41,155 crore in December.
  • Mid-cap funds saw a 4% increase in inflow, totaling ₹5,093 crore.
  • In contrast, large-cap funds experienced a decrease of 21% in inflow, down to ₹2,010 crore.
  • Small-cap mutual funds rose by 13.5% to ₹4,667 crore.
  • Sectoral/thematic funds experienced a remarkable 100% spike, reaching ₹15,331 crore.
  • A total of 33 new fund offers were launched in December.
“The major spike was seen in the inflow of sectoral/thematic funds, which saw a jump of 100% to ₹15,331 crore.”

This growth in inflows indicates a positive trend for equity investments despite fluctuations in large-cap funds, showcasing increasing investor confidence in the market.

item.title: Equity MF inflows rose 15% to Rs 41,000 crore in Dec, debt funds saw outflows of Rs 1.27 lakh crore - The Economic Times
item.description:
Equity MF inflows rose 15% to Rs 41,000 crore in Dec, debt funds saw outflows of Rs 1.27 lakh crore

Publication Date: December 2024

Source: Economic Times

The mutual fund industry recorded a net outflow of Rs 80,509 crore in December 2024, along with an impressive 15% month-on-month increase in equity mutual fund inflows, reaching Rs 41,155 crore.

  • Equity mutual funds saw inflows rise from Rs 35,943 crore in November to Rs 41,155 crore in December.
  • Sectoral and thematic funds attracted the highest inflows totaling Rs 15,331 crore.
  • In CY24, equity mutual funds had total inflows of Rs 3.94 lakh crore.
  • Debt funds experienced a notable outflow of Rs 1.27 lakh crore.
  • Hybrid mutual funds saw a 6% increase in inflows, reaching Rs 4,369 crore.
  • The overall assets under management (AUM) decreased by 2% to Rs 66.66 lakh crore in December.
“Liquid funds observed the highest outflow in December, amounting to Rs 66,532 crore.”

In conclusion, while equity mutual funds demonstrated strong growth in December, the debt segment faced significant withdrawals, highlighting varied investor confidence in different fund categories.
